Message.Title: Futures are up +191. Asia and Europe are up significantly two days now
Message.Msg: Which will we get to today? A reiterated upgrade or downgrade? No one believes INTC will miss earnings, this board has already shown that warnings (all five since 2000) come before the end of the quarter. Have the bear analysts covered their short positions? Is it time to make INTC a Wall Street darling once more and ride her to 30+ by end of year? We have less than two weeks before earnings and renewed guidance for the 2H 2013. Less than two weeks just for INTC, earnings season begins before July 17th. This means that shorts and analysts, who are aware of the technical superiority, have about one week to cover before it gets messy. Or, they can convince themselves that technical superiority, superior product, superior roadmap, and over 50 current design wins will not translate into higher EPS and EPS growth. On the other hand, denial is strong.

Message.Title: Nvidia sees limited shipments of Tegra 4
Message.Msg: Monica's words, not mine ..... NVDA seeing weak Tegra 4 shipments. Although Nvidia has successfully landed Tegra 4 orders from brand vendors such as Toshiba, Asustek Computer and Hewlett-Packard (HP) for their high-end products, because shipment volumes are still limited, sources from the upstream supply chain believe Nvidia may need to wait until the release of its next-generation Tegra 4i processor with integrated 4G LTE support to turn the tables Nvidia's Tegra 4 has advantages in terms of performance, but because of its high price, most brand vendors have turned to choose solutions from China-based makers or MediaTek, which offer strong performance/price ratios. Currently, the Tegra 4 is mainly focusing on mid-range and high-end markets. Toshiba has launched a Tegra 4-based tablet in Japan, using a 10.1-inch PixelPure LED touch panel with a resolution of 2560 by 1600. With an electromagnetic stylus and Bluetooth keyboard, the tablet is priced at JPY89,800 (US$899). HP is set to release a Tegra 4 tablet, the SlateBook x2 in the US in August, adopting a detachable keyboard design with a 10-inch 1920-by-1080 IPS touch panel, 2GB RAM/16GB ROM and support for microSD memory. The system is set to be priced at US$499. In addition to Android, HP also recently release a Tegra 4-based all-in-on PC, priced at US$399, featuring a 21.5-inch 1920-by-1080 touch panel. Meanwhile, Asustek is using the Tegra 4 for its latest Transformer Pad Infinity, which is priced at US$599.

Topic.Title: Nvidia sees limited shipments of Tegra 4

Message.Msg: NVidia's in trouble. Here's Daniel Charlton's commentary: "And the Tegra 4i - you know, the chip that was promised way back at CES 2011 - will be entering mass production some time in early 2014. And in devices some time in Q2 of 2014. That is, if NVIDIA can find anyone willing to buy one. They aren't having much like with the regular Tegra 4. Meanwhile, Qualcomm will be releasing whatever comes after the 800 at that point. So, concerns about the 4i vs. the 800 are about as relevant as concerns about the Snapdragon S4 vs the Exynos 4 Dual. But since NVIDIA acknowledges that the 4i will not even be as powerful as the 4, and early reports suggest that the 800 will outperform the 4, I still don't think the 800 will have trouble standing up against the 4i when it hits market 9 months later" and: "NVIDIA hasn't been able to get Icera modem production up and running. This is why they announced all the details of what came to be the 4i (at the time just calling it project grey) way back at CES 2012 and then failed to deliver the chip that year. They will fail again to put it to market this year. Just like they failed to hit their Q4 2012 release timeframe for the 4." [By the time 4i comes out, it will face not just the 800, but will face Intel's Merrifield, which will have the same kind of advantage for smartphones as we are seeing Bay Trail for tablets]

Topic.Title: Apple just made a huge mistake by signing with TSMC

Message.Msg: The only thing to watch out for is if Apple sticks with the 40nm node from TSMC. And if it's truly a year out then the next node Apple may want from TSMC may be 28nm. I have faith that by next year TSMC can finally make 28nm in sizable enough yields to satisfy Apple. ---- Apple is currently using Samsung's 32nm node, and there is no way they can go 'back' to 40nm. There was talk of the A5 in the latest version of Apple TV being the first (Samsung) 28nm part, but it looks like this is still 32nm, but a complete redesign which resulted in a smaller die. TSMC doesn't have (general) yield issues on the LP 28nm node, the biggest issue is capacity. I doubt Apple will use TSMC for 28nm. My bet, you'll see this years Apples A* processors staying with Samsung, but dropping to 28nm. As for , "iPhone will feel a bit sluggish compared to Intel based Android phones". Apple has a huge advantage in that their environment is native. Basically you are talking native code V Java so Apple could be quite far back on (real) CPU performance but the app will still perform better on their platform (Android's Java stack is poor) . Also, Apples GPU's are far ahead of anyone else which is a big driver for the fluid UI.

Message.Title: Intel’s Justin Rattner on New Laser Chip Business
Message.Msg: technologyreviewDotcom/news/516311/intels-justin-rattner-on-new-laser-chip-business . . . . It’s a 100-gigabit-per-second transceiver [a device that sends data between computers along an optical fiber]. We use conventional CMOS [chip] fabrication techniques to actually build the lasers into the chip. We showed a 50-gigabit-per-second link a few years ago that was built in the lab (see “Computing at the Speed of Light”); the current chip can do 100 gigabits per second, but the connector, which we teamed up with Corning to build, has the ability to go to 1.6 terabits per second. In the data center—[meaning] more bandwidth at much lower cost, and what looks like a big win on the energy-efficiency side. The data center guys love all this capacity but with cables that are teeny-tiny. Right now most data centers are running at 10 gigabits per second; a few people have deployed 40 gigabits per second. People at Facebook [have] begun to think about other applications for silicon photonics [inside server] racks. . . . .

Message.Title: THIS IS WHY SAMSUNG GOING WITH INTEL
Message.Msg: the Exynos 5 Octa, the chip may not be all it’s cracked up to be. by justfine790 • Jun 2, 2013 11:56 AM From the Android Authority; The Exynos 5 Octa and the State of Samsung SoCs by Daniel Charlton "All of this leads up to the Exynos 5 Octa and the Galaxy S4. The Octa is used in the GT-I9500 variant of the Galaxy S4 and is supposed to solve the problem of Cortex-A15 power consumption by using ARM’s big.LITTLE architecture. big.LITTLE allows the use of two core clusters, one for high-performance tasks and one for low-performance tasks. In the Octa, this is a quad-core Cortex-A15 cluster and a quad-core Cortex-A7 cluster, all built on 28nm. In big.LITTLE, there are supposed to be three modes for managing threads across all of the cores in both clusters. Evidence thus far suggests that the Octa really only supports one of these modes – the least efficient. Even worse, it appears that this limitation is due to crippled hardware in the SoC and not something that can be fixed in software" "According to Samsung, there is no hardware problem at all and the company chose cluster-migration because it “show[s] increased performance/efficiency.” But the statement does not match up with most people’s understanding of ARM’s big.LITTLE architecture. Moreover, ARM demonstrated core-migration working on a pre-release version of the Octa. And Samsung’s released kernel source code for the Octa includes the drivers for core-migration. But that code does not work in the final release version of the Octa and Samsung has been coy in giving a straight answer. Based on this, Linus Torvalds wrote:“quite frankly, the fact that the Exynos 5 currently only works in ‘either or’ configuration almost certainly means that there is something fundamentally wrong with the hardware design, to the point where no amount of ‘complex patches’ can fix it.” While this certainly makes it seem that Samsung has done something wrong in the Octa, the chip is still entirely based on desigfrom ARM."

Message.Title: Intel Poised to Explode Upward on Earnings
Message.Msg: Today is yet another example of Wall Street being able to manipulate and sit on the Intel stock price with the extensive use of downgrades, lowered price targets, opinion pieces, money and leverage. Come earnings this is going to disappear. I believe that earnings will bring significant and overwhelmingly positive news. Why do I think this? Well, for the simple reason that we already know about most of this news: Intel Silvermont: Huge success Haswell: Huge success Bay Trail: Huge success FinFet: Huge success with 14nm volume procduction just around the corner Airmont: A total game changer that is not that far off Tablets and new form factors: Tablet sales are doubling each quarter Smartphones: Growth is beginning to accelerate Dual Boot: Another huge advantage in the marketplace XP Replacement Wave: Should accelerate into the second half Growing relationship with Samsung Significant Mac refresh will drive sales Smartwatch release due by the end of the year ARM Major drop in the stock price due to looming competition with Intel Damaged and uncertain roadmap: Arrival of 20nm in volume quantities is unknown 20nm is planar with limited performance increases and damaged economics ARM FinFET is a half-step and may never come to market due to the immense complexity Shrinking margins and profits RT failure to launch No success in addressing the server markets No dual boot Conclusion: It's clear what has happened, what is happening and what will happen. Earnings will provide the granular information necessary to drive a stake through the heart of Wall Street's denial...

Topic.Title: Apple just made a huge mistake by signing with TSMC

Message.Msg: Well, there are three things that most people are ignoring when it comes to the potential of Apple making a major move to Intel: 1.) The market is changing rapidly, especially with Intel. The speed with which Intel is moving has probably caused Apple to have to totally reconsider its roadmap going forward. I think the Altera switch was really their wake-up call and that wasn't very long ago. It takes a huge amount of work to consider a change and project out the effects. 2.) It takes a very long time to engineer a change once a decision is made- literally years for a move to x86 from ARM. I don't think Intel is going to make ARM chips for the simple reason that they don't need to. They will fill their capacity without Apple. Intel is in the driver's seat because of the clear superiority of their technology and manufacturing. 3.) Even if Apple had made the decision to change, they wouldn't tell anyone until they absolutely had to. We have known for a long time that 14nm was the sweet spot for Apple to make a change. That would mean late 2014 or more likely 2015 for the change. If that were the case, no one would know yet and Apple would still be a very long way from any announcement. Bottom line: We still don't really know anything about where the Intel-Apple relationship is going except in the short-term. I think the iWatch will be an exception. We should find out if that is an Intel deal in 3-6 months...

Topic.Title: Apple just made a huge mistake by signing with TSMC

Message.Msg: Hey Blue, Yes, that was exactly what I was thinking but you are a bit more developed in your analysis. Anyway, that argument reminds me of the days when Apple said it's RISC processor was twice as fast as Intel's X86. It turned out it was maybe 15 to 30 percent faster at the same speed, but a 1.5ghz Mac wasn't comparable to a 3ghz Intel processor. I think Apple will once again jump to Intel not so much on speed issues but their upgrade cycle being once again faster than RISC. But as we saw before it took years to make this jump. If Intel makes the A line of processors this would speed up the transition. Intel and Apple always come up with good stuff when they work together such as Thunderbolt 2. Can you imagine what tweaks they could put on the A line of processors?

That's what the ARM drop told us. ARM's dropping P/E ratio should have been Intel's gain. This focus on earnings in the upcoming earnings date is absolutely the wrong focus. The focus should be on Intel getting a fair P/E ratio. It should be on guidance and it should be on the future. The tipping point has been reached and the ARM era is over. Let's see Wall Street come out of denial and give Intel it's due - a significantly higher P/E ratio that accurately reflects the future... ]

Message.Title: Buy a flash kit maker now, Seagate... good ones will be gone soon
Message.Msg: Interesting article on flash storage from the Register. Excerpt: Blocks and Files With Western Digital buying sTec and SanDisk buying SMART Storage Systems, Seagate is looking like the last player standing in the game of flash musical chairs. These days, a lot of serious storage suppliers are keen to get into enterprise flash storage devices - meaning component devices and not complete arrays such as those supplied by Nimbus Data, Pure Storage, Violin Memory and Whiptail. There are basically three NAND storage device form factors: SSDs using Fibre Channel; SAS and SATA interfaces; and PCIe interface cards. In very broad strokes, the current state of the main enterprise SSD and PCIe players and wannabe players is this:

Topic.Title: Apple is rated "AVOID " Intel gets its commupance as Apple "AVOIDS" IT

Message.Msg: If you feel that way, you should sell, short, buy puts and take that action now. One of the worst investment strategies is to wait for a stock you view as a DOG, to "come back" while you could be making TONS of money on other stocks. You should find your courage to take your losses and move on to something that will perform better, recoup your losses and allow you to sleep better. If you have a big loss, I would not want to follow your advice and then follow in your footsteps. If you have a small loss, then what's the big deal? Sell and move on. Alternatively, you sell call options on your position, (assuming more than 100 shares) and generate some extra income while you are waiting. BTW, You don't speak for "us shareholders". Many of "us shareholders" have a profitable position and are quite happy.

Topic.Title: S&P UPGRADES OPINION ON SHARES OF INTEL TO BUY FROM HOLD

Message.Msg: Sell your shares and then WRITE (sell) a Jan $28 put option for $4.65/$4.75. You can pocket the 65 cents per share and when Intel reaches $28, the put options expire worthless. If Jan arrives and Intel is still below $28, just roll the put option out 3 months for another credit. If you get LEVEL 3 option qualified by your broker, you can free up the cash of the underlying Intel position for use elsewhere.

Message.Title: Tizen on the backburner?
Message.Msg: From Forbes: :Samsung may have hit some problems here. Its project to build a new open source operating system for potentially cheaper mobile devices with Intel INTC +1.21%, called Tizen, has reportedly been delayed from the third-quarter to the end of the year, allegedly due to problems getting developer support for its app store. In the second quarter of 2013, developers showd more interested in producing apps for Windows Phone and Firefox OS than Tizen, according to a recent study of more than 6,000 developers by Appcelerator and research firm IDC" At first it looks like bad news for Intel. Tizen may be downgraded in importance. But the key take-away from this article is that Samsung and Intel are working closer together on some Android related project. Today app developers seem to be able to pick and choose who and what they want to work with. Microsoft and now Apple are pleading with them for attention. The smartphone market is too mature now to take on new operating systems and many wonder if Microsoft is too late. I don't expect Firefox OS to go anywhere. When looking at the smartphone market I am glad Intel is putting more eggs in the basket of the well established operating systems instead of confusing the market with more choices. It's going to be iOS and Android with Windows Phone leading the pack of the unknowns. Intel will probably put Tizen to work with things like embedded devices where it can be boiled down to just the basics. Less
